009package imagingbook.common.corners;
010
011import static imagingbook.common.math.Arithmetic.EPSILON_DOUBLE;
012import static imagingbook.common.math.Arithmetic.isZero;
013import static imagingbook.common.math.Arithmetic.sqr;
014import static imagingbook.common.math.Matrix.add;
015import static imagingbook.common.math.Matrix.distL2;
016import static imagingbook.common.math.Matrix.dotProduct;
017import static imagingbook.common.math.Matrix.multiply;
018import static imagingbook.common.math.Matrix.normL2;
019
020import imagingbook.common.util.Enums.Description;
021
022/**
023 * <p>
024 * Common interface for all sub-pixel maximum locator implementations.
025 * A  sub-pixel maximum locator tries to interpolate the continuous position
026 * and value of a local maximum for a discrete 3x3 neighborhood.
027 * The center value in the discrete neighborhood is assumed to be a local maximum.
028 * See Sec. 6.5 and Appendix E of [1] for additional details.
029 * </p>
030 * <p>
031 * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing - An Algorithmic Approach</em>,
032 * 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
033 * </p>
034 * 
035 * @see QuadraticTaylor
036 * @see QuadraticLeastSquares
037 * @see Quartic
038 * @author WB
039 * @version 2021/01/19
040 * @version 2022/09/11 revised instance creation
041 */
042public abstract class SubpixelMaxInterpolator {
043        
044        private SubpixelMaxInterpolator() {}
045        
046        /**
047         * Tries to locate the sub-pixel maximum from the 9 discrete sample values
048         * (s0,...,s8) taken from a 3x3 neighborhood, arranged in the following order:
049         * <pre>
050         * s4 s3 s2
051         * s5 s0 s1
052         * s6 s7 s8
053         * </pre>
054         * The center value (s0) is associated with position (0,0).
055         * 
056         * @param s a vector containing 9 sample values in the order described above
057         * @return a 3-element array [x,y,z], with the estimated maximum position (x,y) 
058         * and the associated max. value (z). 
059         * The position is relative to the center coordinate (0,0).
060         * {@code null} is returned if the maximum position could not be located.
061         */
062        public abstract float[] getMax(float[] s);
063        
064        /**
065         * Enumeration of different {@link SubpixelMaxInterpolator} methods.
066         */
067        public enum Method {
068                @Description("Quadratic Taylor Interpolation") 
069                QuadraticTaylor(SubpixelMaxInterpolator.QuadraticTaylor.getInstance()),
070                
071                @Description("Quadratic Least-Squares Interpolation") 
072                QuadraticLeastSquares(SubpixelMaxInterpolator.QuadraticLeastSquares.getInstance()),
073                
074                @Description("Quartic Interpolation") 
075                Quartic(SubpixelMaxInterpolator.Quartic.getInstance()),
076                
077                @Description("No Interpolation") 
078                None(null);
079                
080                private final SubpixelMaxInterpolator inst;
081                
082                private Method(SubpixelMaxInterpolator instance) {
083                        this.inst = instance;
084                }
085                
086                public SubpixelMaxInterpolator getInstance() {
087                        return this.inst;
088                }
089        }
090        
091        // ------------------------------------------------------------------------------
092        
093        /**
094         * <p>
095         * 2D interpolator using second-order Taylor expansion to find the coefficients
096         * of the quadratic interpolating polynomial 
097         * </p>
098         * <pre>f(x,y) = c_0 + c_1 x + c_2 y + c_3 x^2 + c_4 y^2  + c_5 xy</pre>
099         * <p>
100         * The resulting function fits exactly the 5 on-axis samples 
101         * (s[0], s[1], s[3], s[5], s[7]) but in general does not pass
102         * through the outer diagonal samples (s[2], s[4], s[6], s[8]).
103         * See Appendix E.2.2 (Alg. E.1, 'FindMaxQuadraticTaylor') of [1] for 
104         * additional details.
105         * </p>
106         * <p>
107         * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing - An Algorithmic Approach</em>,
108         * 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
109         * </p>
110         */
111        public static class QuadraticTaylor extends SubpixelMaxInterpolator {
112                
113                private static final QuadraticTaylor instance = new QuadraticTaylor();
114                private QuadraticTaylor() {};
115                public static QuadraticTaylor getInstance() {
116                        return instance;
117                }
118                
119                private final double[] c = new double[6];       // polynomial coefficients
120
121                @Override
122                public float[] getMax(float[] s) {
123                        c[0] = s[0];
124                        c[1] = (s[1] - s[5]) / 2;
125                        c[2] = (s[7] - s[3]) / 2;
126                        c[3] = (s[1] - 2*s[0] + s[5]) / 2;
127                        c[4] = (s[3] - 2*s[0] + s[7]) / 2;
128                        c[5] = (-s[2] + s[4] - s[6] + s[8]) / 4;
129                        
130                        double d = (4*c[3]*c[4] - sqr(c[5]));   // determinant of Hessian
131                        
132                        if (d < EPSILON_DOUBLE || c[3] >= 0) {  // undefined or not a maximum
133                                return null;
134                        }
135                        
136                        // max position:
137                        float x = (float) ((c[2]*c[5] - 2*c[1]*c[4]) / d);
138                        float y = (float) ((c[1]*c[5] - 2*c[2]*c[3]) / d);
139                        // max value:
140                        float z = (float) (c[0] + c[1]*x + c[2]*y + c[3]*x*x + c[4]*y*y + c[5]*x*y);
141                        return new float[] {x, y, z};
142                }
143        }
144        
145        /**
146         * 2D interpolator using second-order Taylor expansion to find the coefficients
147         * of the quadratic interpolating polynomial 
148         * <pre>f(x,y) = c_0 + c_1 x + c_2 y + c_3 x^2 + c_4 y^2  + c_5 xy</pre>
149         * The resulting function fits exactly the 5 on-axis samples 
150         * (s[0], s[1], s[3], s[5], s[7]) but in general does not pass
151         * through the outer diagonal samples (s[2], s[4], s[6], s[8]).
152         * Alternate version using explicit inverse Hessian.
153         */
154        @SuppressWarnings("unused")
155        private static class QuadraticTaylorAlt extends SubpixelMaxInterpolator {
156                
157                private static final QuadraticTaylorAlt instance = new QuadraticTaylorAlt();
158                private QuadraticTaylorAlt() {};
159                public static QuadraticTaylorAlt getInstance() {
160                        return instance;
161                }
162
163                @Override
164                public float[] getMax(float[] s) {
165                        double[] g = {                                                  // the gradient
166                                        (s[1] - s[5]) / 2, 
167                                        (s[7] - s[3]) / 2};     
168                        
169                        double H00 = s[1] - 2*s[0] + s[5];              // elements of the Hessian matrix
170                        double H11 = s[3] - 2*s[0] + s[7];
171                        double H01 = (s[4] + s[8] - s[2] - s[6]) / 4;                   
172                        double d = H00 * H11 - sqr(H01);                // = det(H)
173                        
174                        if (d < EPSILON_DOUBLE || H00 >= 0) {   // not a maximum (minimum or saddle point)
175                                return null;
176                        }
177                        
178                        double[][] Hi = {                       // inverse Hessian
179                                        { H11 / d, -H01 / d}, 
180                                        {-H01 / d,  H00 / d}};  
181                        
182                        double[] delta = multiply(Hi, g);
183                        double[] xy = multiply(-1, delta);                              // maximum position
184                        double q = s[0] - 0.5 * dotProduct(g, delta);   // maximum value
185                        return new float[] {(float) xy[0], (float) xy[1], (float) q};
186                }
187        }
188        
189        // ------------------------------------------------------------------------------
190        
191        /**
192         * <p>
193         * 2D interpolator based on least-squares fitting a quadratic polynomial 
194         * </p>
195         * <pre>f(x,y) = c_0 + c_1 x + c_2 y + c_3 x^2 + c_4 y^2  + c_5 xy</pre>
196         * <p>to the supplied sample values.
197         * See Sec. E.2.3 (Alg. E2, 'FindMaxQuadraticLeastSquares') of [1] for
198         * additional details.
199         * </p>
200         * <p>
201         * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing - An Algorithmic Approach</em>,
202         * 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
203         * </p>
204         */
205        public static class QuadraticLeastSquares extends SubpixelMaxInterpolator {
206                
207                private static final QuadraticLeastSquares instance = new QuadraticLeastSquares();
208                private QuadraticLeastSquares() {};
209                public static QuadraticLeastSquares getInstance() {
210                        return instance;
211                }
212                
213                private final double[] c = new double[6];       // polynomial coefficients
214
215                @Override
216                public float[] getMax(float[] s) {
217                        c[0] = (5 * s[0] + 2 * s[1] - s[2] + 2 * s[3] - s[4] + 2 * s[5] - s[6] + 2 * s[7] - s[8]) / 9;
218                        c[1] = (s[1] + s[2] - s[4] - s[5] - s[6] + s[8]) / 6;
219                        c[2] = (-s[2] - s[3] - s[4] + s[6] + s[7] + s[8]) / 6;
220                        c[3] = (-2 * s[0] + s[1] + s[2] - 2 * s[3] + s[4] + s[5] + s[6] - 2 * s[7] + s[8]) / 6;
221                        c[4] = (-2 * s[0] - 2 * s[1] + s[2] + s[3] + s[4] - 2 * s[5] + s[6] + s[7] + s[8]) / 6;
222                        c[5] = (-s[2] + s[4] - s[6] + s[8]) / 4;
223                        
224                        double d = (4*c[3]*c[4] - sqr(c[5]));
225                        
226                        if (d < EPSILON_DOUBLE || c[3] >= 0) {  // not a maximum (minimum or saddle point)
227                                return null;
228                        }
229                        
230                        // max position:
231                        float x = (float) ((c[2]*c[5] - 2*c[1]*c[4]) / d);
232                        float y = (float) ((c[1]*c[5] - 2*c[2]*c[3]) / d);
233                        // max value:
234                        float z = (float) (c[0] + c[1]*x + c[2]*y + c[3]*x*x + c[4]*y*y + c[5]*x*y);
235                        return new float[] {x, y, z};
236                }
237        }
238        
239        // ------------------------------------------------------------------------------
240        
241        /**
242         * <p>
243         * 2D interpolator based on fitting a 'quartic' (i.e., 4th-order) polynomial
244         * </p>
245         * <pre>
246         * f(x,y) = c_0 + c_1 x + c_2 y + c_3 x^2 + c_4 y^2 + c_5 x y + c_6 x^2 y + c_7 x y^2 + c_8 x^2 y^2</pre>
247         * <p>
248         * to the supplied sample values. The interpolation function passes through
249         * all sample values. The local maximum cannot be found in closed form but 
250         * is found iteratively, which is not guaranteed to succeed.
251         * See Appendix E.2.4 (Alg. E.3, 'FindMaxQuartic') of [1] for 
252         * additional details.
253         * </p>
254         * <p>
255         * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing - An Algorithmic Approach</em>,
256         * 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
257         * </p>
258         */
259        public static class Quartic extends SubpixelMaxInterpolator {
260                public static final int DefaultMaxIterations = 20;      // iteration limit
261                public static final double DefaulMaxDelta = 1e-6;       // smallest x/y move to continue search 
262                public static final double DefaultMaxRad = 1.0;         // x/y search boundary (-xyLimit, +xyLimit)
263                
264                private final int maxIterations;
265                private final double maxDelta;
266                private final double maxRad;
267                
268                private final double[] c = new double[9];       // polynomial coefficients
269                
270                private static final Quartic instance = new Quartic();
271                
272                private Quartic() {
273                        this(DefaultMaxIterations, DefaulMaxDelta, DefaultMaxRad);
274                }
275                
276                private Quartic(int maxIterations, double maxDelta, double maxRad) {
277                        this.maxIterations = maxIterations;
278                        this.maxDelta = maxDelta;
279                        this.maxRad = maxRad;
280                }
281                
282                public static Quartic getInstance() {
283                        return instance;
284                }
285                
286                public static Quartic getInstance(int maxIterations, double maxDelta, double maxRad) {
287                        return new Quartic(maxIterations, maxDelta, maxRad);
288                }
289                
290                // -----------------------------------------------------------
291                
292                @Override
293                public float[] getMax(float[] s) {
294                        c[0] = s[0];
295                        c[1] = (s[1] - s[5]) / 2;
296                        c[2] = (s[7] - s[3]) / 2;
297                        c[3] = (s[1] - 2 * s[0] + s[5]) / 2;
298                        c[4] = (s[3] - 2 * s[0] + s[7]) / 2;
299                        c[5] = (-s[2] + s[4] - s[6] + s[8]) / 4;
300                        c[6] = (-s[2] + 2 *s[3] - s[4] + s[6] - 2 * s[7] + s[8]) / 4;
301                        c[7] = (-2 * s[1] + s[2] - s[4] + 2 * s[5] - s[6] + s[8]) / 4;
302                        c[8] = s[0] + (-2 * s[1] + s[2] - 2 * s[3] + s[4] - 2 * s[5] + s[6] - 2 * s[7] + s[8]) / 4;
303                        
304                        // iteratively find the max location:
305                        boolean done = false;
306                        int n = 0;
307                        double[] xCur = {0, 0};
308                        double H00 = 0, H11 = 0, H01 = 0, d = 0;
309                        while (!done && n < maxIterations && normL2(xCur) < maxRad) {
310                                double[] g = this.getGradient(xCur);
311                                double[][] H = this.getHessian(xCur);
312                                H00 = H[0][0];
313                                H11 = H[1][1];
314                                H01 = H[0][1];
315                                d = H00 * H11 - sqr(H01);
316                                if (isZero(d)) {
317//                                      throw new RuntimeException(Quartic.class.getSimpleName() + ": zero determinant");
318                                        return null;
319                                }
320                                double[][] Hi = {                       // inverse Hessian
321                                                { H11 / d, -H01 / d}, 
322                                                {-H01 / d,  H00 / d}};  
323                                double[] xNext = add(xCur, multiply(multiply(-1, Hi), g));
324                                if (distL2(xCur, xNext) < maxDelta) {
325                                        done = true;
326                                }
327                                else {
328                                        xCur[0] = xNext[0];
329                                        xCur[1] = xNext[1];
330                                        n = n + 1;
331                                }
332                        }
333                        
334                        boolean isMax = (d > 0) && (H00 < 0);   // false if saddle point or relative minimum
335                        
336                        if (done && isMax) {
337                                float z = (float) getInterpolatedValue(xCur);
338                                return new float[] {(float) xCur[0], (float) xCur[1], z};
339                        }
340                        else {
341                                return null;
342                        }
343                }
344                
345                private double getInterpolatedValue(double[] X) {
346                        final double x = X[0];
347                        final double y = X[1];
348                        return c[0] + c[1]*x + c[2]*y + c[3]*x*x + c[4]*y*y
349                                                + c[5]*x*y + c[6]*x*x*y + c[7]*x*y*y + c[8]*x*x*y*y;
350                }
351                
352                private double[] getGradient(double[] X) {
353                        return this.getGradient(X[0], X[1]);
354                }
355
356                private double[] getGradient(double x, double y) {
357                        double gx = c[1] + 2*c[3]*x + c[5]*y + 2*c[6]*x*y + c[7]*y*y + 2*c[8]*x*y*y;
358                        double gy = c[2] + c[5]*x + 2*c[4]*y + 2*c[7]*x*y + c[6]*x*x + 2*c[8]*x*x*y;
359                        return new double[] {gx, gy};
360                }
361                
362                private double[][] getHessian(double[] X) {
363                        return this.getHessian(X[0], X[1]);
364                }
365                
366                private double[][] getHessian(double x, double y) {
367                        final double H00 = 2*(c[3] + y*(c[6] + c[8]*y));
368                        final double H11 = 2*(c[4] + x*(c[7] + c[8]*x));
369                        final double H01 = c[5] + 2*c[6]*x + 2*c[7]*y + 4*c[8]*x*y;
370                        double[][] Hi = {
371                                        { H00, H01}, 
372                                        { H01, H11}};
373                        return Hi;
374                }
375                
376        }
377}
